instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2159: What is A2159? A2159 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2019 with EMC 3301, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01598..
definitions.820-01598: What is 820-01598? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS: What is PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS? PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS is 20v in from the USB-C charger on USB-C powered Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..
definitions.PP3V3_S0SW_LCD: What is PP3V3_S0SW_LCD? PP3V3_S0SW_LCD is a 3.3v power rail necessary to power the image circuitry on the screen. This is necessary to get a picture on the screen. .
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP3V3_G3S: What is PP3V3_G3S? PP3V3_G3S is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in a G3S standby state. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) liquid damage, <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> power cycles to 5V
threads.message:
Hi guys,

<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> with very minor liquid damage, most likely water. Cleaned in the ultrasonic twice.
No components are visually damaged, badly corroded or burnt. There were smoke traces of 20V short on the USB pcb connector.
Before cleaning there was no PD negotiation (5V, 0.4A). After cleaning, 20V is back.

Power on USB-C input is power cycling between 0.038 and 0.089A (20V). 
Using original 90W charger, also tested 65W original.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.36V (slight dip to 12.26V every 3s)
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 20.30V
<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XA_VBUS</SIGNAL> 20.30V (depending on which is connected)
<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS</SIGNAL> 20.30V ^
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.3V (slight dip to 2.26V every 3s)
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> 0.02V jumps to 5V every 3 seconds or so, 21kOhm to gnd
Confirmed with scope it is exactly 3.5s, attempt to power <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> on.

<CHIP>U7650</CHIP> looks fine, but:
<RESISTOR>R7672</RESISTOR> measures 0.945k (datasheet says 4.4k)
<RESISTOR>R7673</RESISTOR> measures 0.945k (datasheet says 1.2k)
<SIGNAL>P5VG3S_CSP1</SIGNAL> (pin 7) pulsing 5V, pin 8 same.

I have looked around various rails for shorts, but have yet to find anything suspicious.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) liquid damage, <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> power cycles to 5V
threads.message:
Onboard readings for resistors value are always lower than nominal value; in case of K/M range.

Do you get steady <SIGNAL>3V3_G3S</SIGNAL>?
What about <SIGNAL>1V8_G3S</SIGNAL>?
Also check all AWAKE and SLPS2R voltages, if stable.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) liquid damage, <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> power cycles to 5V
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_G3S</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>1V8_G3S</SIGNAL> both power cycling (can barely see blip with multimeter, would have to test with scope), both kOhms to gnd.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 3.25V shows for about 1s, then 0 for 2s. <SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> same, 1.8V for 1s. All mOhm to gnd.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) liquid damage, <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> power cycles to 5V
threads.message:
So all power rails are pulsing.
Check for short on all big coils (from secondary supplies).

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) liquid damage, <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> power cycles to 5V
threads.message: The only coils near short are the CPU coils at around 3.4ohm, PVCCEDRAM around 30ohm, PVCCIO around 70ohm.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) liquid damage, <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> power cycles to 5V
threads.message: Can you catch any pulse on S3, or S0 power rails?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) liquid damage, <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> power cycles to 5V
threads.message:
Remove audio board and check for liquid sign on both sides.
Also inspect audio flex and both connectors.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) liquid damage, <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> power cycles to 5V
threads.message: I'm doing all this with the logic board out of the case. Nothing connected except USB ports.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) liquid damage, <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> power cycles to 5V
threads.message:
And is dificult to check what I've asked you???
We need to know if T2 data lines might be affected for liquid spill on audio board.

threads.message: Sorry, I misunderstood. Going to check the audio board in a bit.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) liquid damage, <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> power cycles to 5V
threads.message:
Is that corrosion?
Check the other side, around audio amplifier.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) liquid damage, <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> power cycles to 5V
threads.message: Yeah, looks like very slight corrosion. The liquid sensor is red. I don't see anything else that looks bad/corroded.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) liquid damage, <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> power cycles to 5V
threads.message:
Leakage from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> to T2 data lines is what probably happened.
In such case, it is garbage now.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) liquid damage, <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> power cycles to 5V
threads.message: Any way to make sure?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) liquid damage, <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> power cycles to 5V
threads.message:
Wait, you have 01598 board, not 01958; mea culpa, sorry.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> doesn't go to J6600, but 16V for Touch ID.
If your picture is for Touch ID connector, from audio board, very likely that corrosion damaged T2.
Just in case, check diode mode to ground on T2 data lines, related with Touch ID; all of them have "MESA" in the name.
Compare with similar working board, if available.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) liquid damage, <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> power cycles to 5V
threads.message:
All of the MESA lines are mOhm, a few kOhm, but nothing to compare to.
I tried connecting the board to another Mac and interestingly it takes 4.91V and stable 0.45A (about 2W).
The only areas that get warm are under the can (<CHIP>U3900</CHIP>, northbridge?) and L7030 (<SIGNAL>CHGR_LX1</SIGNAL>), but nothing around <SIGNAL>CHGR_LX1</SIGNAL> is shorted.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) liquid damage, <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> power cycles to 5V
threads.message:
<CHIP>U3900</CHIP> is the f***g T2.

Do not use ohm scale when you check data lines to ground; diode mode is the way for comparison.

So no pulsing power on other shell?
Check all power rails above mentioned.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) liquid damage, <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> power cycles to 5V
threads.message:
So, connected to computer USB, input showing 4.91V, 0.3955A stable.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.26V stable
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> 12.26V stable
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 4.69V stable
<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XA_VBUS</SIGNAL> 4.87V stable
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> 3.30V stable
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.23V stable
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 3.23V stable
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 1.8V stable
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 1.2V stable
<SIGNAL>PPVDDCPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 0.75V stable

<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> 0.0V no pulse
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3S</SIGNAL> 0.0V no pulse
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_G3S</SIGNAL> 0.0V no pulse
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> 0.0V no pulse
<SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> 0.0V no pulse
<SIGNAL>P5VG3S_CSP1</SIGNAL> 0.0V no pulse

I don't know what the behavior should be on 5V and no battery, but I think it's okay it doesn't allow boot (correct me if I'm wrong).

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) liquid damage, <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> power cycles to 5V
threads.message: Test the board alone on the desk; nothing connected, apart of charger.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) liquid damage, <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> power cycles to 5V
threads.message: I'm doing all testing since the beginning with the board only.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) liquid damage, <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> power cycles to 5V
threads.message:
Machine can go into DFU with 5V from other machine; the one with AC2 installed.
Connection must be done through dedicated USB-C port.
You can use SE032 pads, to force it in DFU without keyboard.

If you connect normal USB-C charger, it should boot directly.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) liquid damage, <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> power cycles to 5V
threads.message:
Weird, I can't get any sign of life.
I tried USB-A to USB-C, both ports, with and without plugging charger in. Also tried connecting SE032 pads.
Then tried USB-C to USB-C (12" Macbook Retina), with and without charger, SE032 pads.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) liquid damage, <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> power cycles to 5V
threads.message: Did you get <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and all AWAKE and SLPS2R voltages?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) liquid damage, <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> power cycles to 5V
threads.message: Yes. What I meant by "no sign of life" was on the USB. Nothing shows up in AC2.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) liquid damage, <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> power cycles to 5V
threads.message:
SE032 pads are usually used in case of no charger, only connection to AC2 machine.
If charger is connected, should go into DFU with keyboard, or SE032 pads.
There must be something wrong with T2, or corresponding USB-C port.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) liquid damage, <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> power cycles to 5V
threads.message: Does the entire metal shield have to be removed to see the T2 or is it partially open when the black sticker is removed?
